revision.text:
{{Infobox civil conflict | title = 2018 North Carolina teachers' rally | side3= |partof = the [[2018 teachers' strikes in the United States]] | image = | caption = | date = {{Start date|2018|05|16}}– | place= [[Raleigh, North Carolina]] | coordinates = | causes = * Low salaries{{cite web|last1=Scott|first1=Tamara|title=Report: North Carolina ranks 37th in nation for teacher pay|url=http://www.wnct.com/news/local-news/a-new-report-suggests-north-carolina-could-be-the-next-state-to-see-teacher-strikes/1151839964|website=[[WNCT-TV]]|publisher=[[Nexstar Media Group]]|accessdate=May 2, 2018|date=April 30, 2018}} * Deflating wages{{cite web|last1=Elk|first1=Mike|title=North Carolina Teachers to Strike in May – Louisiana Teachers Could Follow – Georgia Bus Drivers Fired for Striking|url=http://paydayreport.com/north-carolina-teachers-to-strike-in-may-louisiana-teachers-could-follow-georgia-bus-drivers-fired-for-striking/|website=paydayreport.com|accessdate=May 2, 2018|date=April 30, 2018}} * Suspension of health benefits for future hirees{{cite web|last1=Strauss|first1=Valerie|title=Could North Carolina’s teachers be next to strike? Here’s the mess they’re in.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/answer-sheet/wp/2018/05/01/could-north-carolinas-teachers-be-next-to-strike-heres-the-mess-theyre-in/|website=washingtonpost.com|publisher=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=May 2, 2018|date=May 1, 2018}} | goals = * Salary increase{{cite web|last1=Yan|first1=Holly|last2=Park|first2=Madison|title=North Carolina teachers want better pay and they're marching to fight for it|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/05/16/us/north-carolina-teachers/index.html|website=[[CNN]]|publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System]]|accessdate=May 16, 2018|date=May 16, 2018}} * Restore of funding to pre-2008 levels * Reinstatement of healthcare benefits for future hirees * Construction board to overlook school repairs | methods = * [[Occupation (protest)|Occupation]] * [[Demonstration (protest)|Demonstrations]] * [[Internet activism]] * [[Walkout]] | status = Ongoing | result = | side1= * [[Democratic Socialists of America|DSA]] * [[Industrial Workers of the World|IWW]] * May 16 Coalition * [[North Carolina Association of Educators|NCAE]] | side2= * [[Government of North Carolina]] * [[North Carolina Republican Party|NCGOP]] * [[North Carolina Democratic Party|NCDP]] | leadfigures1 = Oliver A. Holley
Shammah Barrett
Tiffany Smith | leadfigures2 = [[Roy Cooper]]
[[Harry Brown (American politician)|Harry Brown]]
[[Tim Moore (North Carolina politician)|Tim Moore]] | leadfigures3 = | howmany1 = | howmany2 = | howmany3 = | notes = }} The '''2018 North Carolina teachers' rally''' was a rally and protest that began on May 16, 2018, with teachers in [[North Carolina]] walking out in protest of deflating wages and decreased employee benefits. The rally is part of the larger [[2018 teachers' strikes in the United States|wave of teachers' strikes in the United States]] where protests occurred in [[2018 West Virginia teachers' strike|West Virginia]], [[2018 Oklahoma teachers' strike|Oklahoma]], [[2018 Colorado teachers' strike|Colorado]], and [[2018 Arizona teachers' strike|Arizona]]. == Background == === State of education in North Carolina === Ahead of the protests the average salary for a teacher in North Carolina was $49,970, which ranked 44th in the nation according to a report by the [[National Education Association]].{{cite web|title=Rankings and Estimates Report|url=http://www.nea.org/assets/docs/180413-Rankings_And_Estimates_Report_2018.pdf|website=nea.org|publisher=[[National Education Association]]|pages=25}} Public school revenue per student in North Carolina ranked 43rd in the nation $9,675.{{cite web|title=Rankings and Estimates Report|url=http://www.nea.org/assets/docs/180413-Rankings_And_Estimates_Report_2018.pdf|website=nea.org|publisher=National Education Association|pages=26}} === Demands === The [[North Carolina Association of Educators]] (NCAE) demanded that the [[Government of North Carolina]] enacted legislation that increase per pupil spending, a multi-year pay plan for teachers, support staff, administrators, and all school personnel, which includes the restoration of compensation for longevity and advanced degrees. Additionally, the NCAE demanded that public schools in North Carolina increase the number of school nurses, counselors, social workers and other support personnel and expand Medicaid to improve community health. NCAE also demanded that the state legislature set up a statewide school construction board to fix older schools and reduce large class sizes. == Response == === Government of North Carolina === [[Roy Cooper]], a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], and the [[Governor of North Carolina]], urged local and state officials to stop attacking teachers and unite together to support teachers and schools in the state. Cooper tweeted an editorial of the [[Charlotte Observer]].{{cite web|last1=Cooper|first1=Roy|title=Let’s stop attacking teachers and instead work together to support them and our schools.|url=https://twitter.com/RoyCooperNC/status/995305804155838465?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Etweet|website=@RoyCooperNC|publisher=Twitter}} Members from the [[North Carolina Republican Party]] sent out mass emails to constituents across the state explaining their support for public education and teachers.{{cite web|author1=The Observer Editorial Board|title=The Teachers March is already rattling NC Republicans|url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/opinion/article211234489.html|website=[[The Charlotte Observer]]|publisher=[[The McClatchy Company]]|accessdate=May 16, 2018|date=May 16, 2018}} Joseph Kyzer, a spokesperson for House speaker Tom Moore stated that Republican leadership has continuously raised teachers salaries and that it was Democratic leadership in the state that stalled out spending.{{cite web|last1=Siemaszko|first1=Corky|title=North Carolina teachers to rally in Raleigh for raises, funding|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/north-carolina-teachers-rally-raleigh-raises-funding-n874271|website=[[NBC News]]|publisher=[[NBC]]|accessdate=May 16, 2018|date=May 16, 2018}} Teachers pointed out although salaries have increased, the increases have been modest and lagged far behind the national average, and that despite this, general education funding on supplies and per pupil spending have been continuously cut. A fellow Republican member, [[Mark Brody]], who serves on the board of Union Day School in Waxhaw, N.C., {{cite web|title=Union Day Charter School - About Us |url=https://www.uniondayschool.com/about-us |accessdate=May 15, 2018}} called teachers protesting and the backers of the protest 'Union Thugs', that want to control the education process. Brody said he was speaking up because he did not want his local Union County schools or North Carolina schools in general to turn into Chicago. "Let the Union thugs get their way now and we are half way there," he said.{{cite web|last1=Specht|first1=Paula|title='Teacher Union thugs' are behind education march, NC lawmaker says|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/news/politics-government/article210978129.html|website=[[The News & Observer]]|publisher=[[The McClatchy Company]]|accessdate=May 16, 2018|date=May 11, 2018}} Brody would defend his statement, but emphasize that the "thug" remark was about [[trade unions]], and not the teachers themselves.{{cite web|last1=Giles|first1=Alex|title=State representative speaks about Facebook post where he referenced 'teacher union thugs'|url=http://www.wbtv.com/story/38189132/state-representative-speaks-about-facebook-post-where-he-referenced-teacher-union-thugs|website=[[WBTV]]|publisher=[[Raycom Media]]|accessdate=May 16, 2018|date=May 14, 2018}} === Labor unions === The Raleigh-Durham chapter of the [[Industrial Workers of the World]] helped coordinate transportation for protestors who wished to rally with the teachers in [[Raleigh]].{{cite web|author1=Triangle IWW|title=For those headed to Raleigh on Wednesday, May 16, to support teachers, schools, students, all public sector workers... info about transportation to share widely:|url=https://www.facebook.com/triangleiww/posts/1289641814501608|accessdate=May 16, 2018|date=May 14, 2018}} === Political organizations === Several North Carolina chapters of the [[Democratic Socialists of America]] stood in solidarity with the NCAE, and offered coordination for individuals wishing to join the protest.{{cite web|author1=Greensboro DSA|title=Rain won't stop the thousands of NC teachers gathering in Raleigh from telling the NCGA that we've had enough of austerity education. #RED4Ed #ItsPersonal|url=https://twitter.com/GSO_DSA/status/996710251507470337|date=May 16, 2018}} == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == * [https://may16.org/ May 16 Coalition] {{2018 teachers' strikes in the United States}} {{DEFAULTSORT:North Carolina teacher strike, 2018}} [[Category:2018 in North Carolina]] [[Category:2018 labor disputes and strikes]] [[Category:Education strikes]] [[Category:May 2018 events in the United States]] [[Category:Labor disputes in North Carolina]]

revision.text:
In the [[United States]], '''Advanced Placement (AP) Physics''' collectively refers to the [[College Board]] [[Advanced Placement Program]] courses and exams covering various areas of [[physics]]. These are intended to be equivalent to university courses that use best practices of physics teaching pedagogy.
Each AP Physics course culminates in an optional exam for which high-performing students may receive some credit towards their college coursework, depending on which college or university they attend.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://apstudent.collegeboard.org/creditandplacement | title = Credit & Placement | work = AP Students | publisher = The [[College Board]] | year = 2017 | access-date = January 30, 2017}}</ref>
==AP Physics B (discontinued)== [[AP Physics B]] – discontinued in 2014 – was supposed to be equivalent to an introductory algebra-based college course in physics, with a laboratory component.<ref name="CB09">{{cite web |title=AP Physics B |url= http://www.collegeboard.com/student/testing/ap/sub_physb.html?physicsb| year=2011 |work=AP Central |publisher= [[College Board]]|accessdate=July 24, 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110702141730/http://www.collegeboard.com/student/testing/ap/sub_physb.html?physicsb| archivedate= 2 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= yes}}</ref> The course was non-calculus-based, utilizing [[algebra]] and basic [[trigonometry]] to solve various physics problems.<ref name=Physics2009/> AP Physics B was divided into five different sections: [[Newton's laws of motion|Newtonian Mechanics]], [[Fluid mechanics|Fluid Mechanics]] and [[Thermodynamics|Thermal Physics]], [[Electricity]] and [[Magnetism]], [[Wave]]s and [[Optics]], and [[Atomic physics|Atomic]] and [[Nuclear physics|Nuclear Physics]].<ref name=Physics2009>{{citation|url=http://www.collegeboard.com/prod_downloads/ap/students/physics/ap-cd-physics-0708.pdf |publisher=The [[College Board]] |title=Physics Course Description |date=May 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100601132803/http://www.collegeboard.com/prod_downloads/ap/students/physics/ap-cd-physics-0708.pdf |archivedate=2010-06-01 |df= }}</ref>
AP Physics B was replaced by AP Physics 1 and 2.
==AP Physics 1 and 2== [[AP Physics 1]] and [[AP Physics 2]] were introduced for the 2015 exam administration.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://advancesinap.collegeboard.org/math-and-science/physics | title = AP Physics 1 and 2, 2014–15 | work = AP: Advances in AP | publisher = The College Board | deadurl = yes | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20141018200254/http://advancesinap.collegeboard.org/math-and-science/physics | archive-date = October 18, 2014 }}</ref> The courses were designed to emphasize critical thinking and reasoning as well as learning through inquiry.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://apcentral.collegeboard.com/apc/public/courses/teachers_corner/2262.html | title = AP Physics 1 Course Home Page | work = AP Central | publisher = The College Board | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20141015040347/http://apcentral.collegeboard.com/apc/public/courses/teachers_corner/2262.html | archive-date = October 15, 2014}}</ref> They remain as algebra-based courses that do not require students to have taken calculus.<ref name=CourseAndExam>{{citation | url = http://media.collegeboard.com/digitalServices/pdf/ap/ap-physics-1-and-2-course-and-exam-description.pdf | title = AP® PHYSICS 1: ALGEBRA-BASED AND AP® PHYSICS 2: ALGEBRA-BASED – Course and Exam Description – Effective Fall 2014 | publisher = The College Board | location = New York, NY | year = 2014}}</ref>
AP Physics 1 covers the same Newtonian mechanics as AP Physics B plus rotational mechanics, as well as an introduction to electricity (Coulomb's Law and simple DC circuits), and mechanical waves and sound.<ref name=CourseAndExam/>
AP Physics 2 covers the remaining subjects from AP Physics B: thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, optics, electricity and magnetism, and modern physics.<ref name=CourseAndExam/>
==AP Physics C== The College Board offers two courses in the AP Physics C suite, each equivalent to a semester-length [[calculus]]-based [[college]] course for [[Major (academic)|majors]] in [[Outline of physical science|physical science]] or [[engineering]]:<ref name=PhysCMechoverview/><ref name=PhysCe&mOverview />
* [[AP Physics C: Mechanics]] studies [[Classical mechanics|Newtonian mechanics]], with units on kinematics; Newton’s laws of motion; work, energy, and power; systems of particles and linear momentum; circular motion and rotation; and oscillations and gravitation.<ref name=PhysCMechoverview>{{citation | url = http://media.collegeboard.com/digitalServices/pdf/ap/ap-course-overviews/ap-physics-c-mechanics-course-overview.pdf | format = PDF | title = AP® PHYSICS C: MECHANICS | publisher = [[College Board]] | date = December 2016 | access-date = January 30, 2017}}</ref>
* [[AP Physics C: Electricity and Magnetism]] studies [[electricity]] and [[magnetism]], covering electrostatics; conductors, capacitors, and dielectrics; electric circuits; magnetic fields; and electromagnetism.<ref name=PhysCe&mOverview>{{citation | url = http://media.collegeboard.com/digitalServices/pdf/ap/ap-course-overviews/ap-physics-c-mechanics-course-overview.pdf | format = PDF | title = AP® PHYSICS C: ELECTRICITY & MAGNETISM | publisher = [[College Board]] | date = December 2016 | access-date = January 30, 2017}}</ref>
The two AP Physics C courses can be combined to make a unified Physics C course that prepares for both exams.
== See also == *'''[[Physics]]''' *'''[[Glossary of physics]]'''
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Advanced Placement]] [[Category:Physics education]]

revision.text:
{{infobox Organization |name = Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs |image = ACBSP logo.png |size = 200px |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = ACBSP |motto = |formation = 1989 <ref name=ACBSP>{{cite journal|title=Accreditation: An opportunity for recognition |url=http://www2.aaahq.org/TwoYear/newsletters/2-98comm/inside2.htm |journal=Communicator |publisher=American Accounting Association |date=February 1998 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303231425/http://aaahq.org/TwoYear/newsletters/2-98comm/inside2.htm |archivedate=2016-03-03 |df= }}</ref> |extinction = |type = NGO |status = |purpose = [[educational accreditation]] |headquarters = |location = |region_served = |membership = |language = |leader_title = Key people |leader_name = Dewayne Thompson (Chairman) |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = {{url|www.acbsp.org}} |remarks = }}
The '''Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs''' ('''ACBSP'''), formerly the '''Association of Collegiate Business Schools and Programs''', is a U.S. organization offering [[educational accreditation|accreditation]] services to business programs focused on teaching and learning.<ref>[http://www.acbsp.org/?page=about_us ACBSP Mission], http://www.acbsp.org/?page=about_us</ref>
Based in [[Overland Park]], [[Kansas]] (a suburb of [[Kansas City Metropolitan Area|Kansas City]]), ACBSP was created to fulfill a need for specialized accreditation by colleges and universities with business schools and programs.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP)|url=http://www.collegeatlas.org/acbsp.html|journal=CollegeAtlas.org}}</ref>
== History == ACBSP was founded in 1989 to accredit [[business school]]s with an emphasis on teaching and learning.<ref name=ACBSP/> At the time, only 260 out of 2,400 schools of business had specialized professional accreditation, all from the [[Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business]] (AACSB). Most or all of the AACSB accredited schools had an emphasis on research, while most other schools had an emphasis on teaching. On April 28, 1988, 150 of the non-accredited schools met in Kansas City, Missouri, to consider alternatives to AACSB accreditation for teaching-oriented schools.<ref name=About>[http://www.acbsp.org/p/cm/ld/fid=11 About ACBSP] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100811080827/http://www.acbsp.org/p/cm/ld/fid%3D11 |date=August 11, 2010 }}, ACBSP website, accessed October 27, 2010</ref>
On May 12, 1989, a study group completed a feasibility study and submitted recommendations for standard for accreditation by the ACBSP. In August 1992, ACBSP was recognized by the [[U.S. Department of Education]] as a specialized accreditation agency for business education. In June 1994, a U.S. Department of Education Advisory Committee recommended withdrawal of recognition for the ACBSP due to a determination that ACBSP accreditation would not be a "required element" in making an institution eligible to participate in [[U.S. federal government]] programs under the [[Higher Education Act of 1965|Higher Education Act]] or other authorities.<ref name=meeting1995>[http://www2.ed.gov/legislation/FedRegister/other/1995-4/fr13oc5a.html National Advisory Committee on Institutional Quality and Integrity, Notice of public meeting] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926074308/http://www2.ed.gov/legislation/FedRegister/other/1995-4/fr13oc5a.html |date=September 26, 2011 }}, ''Federal Register'', October 13, 1995 (Volume 60, Number 198), Page 53345-53347</ref> However, at its meeting on January 22, 2001, the [[Council for Higher Education Accreditation]] (CHEA) Board of Directors granted recognition to the ACBSP.<ref>[http://www.chea.org/Directories/special.asp CHEA Directory] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140923101401/http://www.chea.org/Directories/special.asp |date=2014-09-23 }}</ref> On September 19, 2011 The CHEA renewed its recognition of the ACBSP for a further 10 years.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.chea.org/pdf/Recognition/2011_09_20_Recognition%20Summary%20for%20ACBSP.pdf |title=CHEA Recognition Summary |access-date=2011-10-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304090157/http://www.chea.org/pdf/Recognition/2011_09_20_Recognition%20Summary%20for%20ACBSP.pdf |archive-date=2016-03-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
In June 2010, the ACBSP changed its name from Association of Collegiate Business Schools and Programs to Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs.<ref>[http://www.acbsp.org/p/cm/ld/fid=11 About ACBSP] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100811080827/http://www.acbsp.org/p/cm/ld/fid%3D11 |date=August 11, 2010 }}, ACBSP website, accessed October 27, 2010</ref><ref>[http://www.acbsp.org/?page=chea_recognition ], ACBSP CHEA</ref> The ACBSP accredits mostly business schools with traditional campus locations, but also accredits online business programs as well.
== Membership == As of August 2010, ACBSP reported having over 8,000 individual members and 828 member educational institutions, of which 529 had ACBSP accreditation and 220 had candidacy status. All but 134 member institutions are in the United States.<ref name=About/> In April 2013, ACBSP reported 1,171 member campuses, 183 of which are located outside of the U.S. Of those campuses, 586 have achieved accreditation and more than 500 are in candidacy for accreditation. Individual members on these campuses now exceed 10,000.<ref>[http://www.acbsp.org/?page=history ACBSP Website - History] Retrieved January 25, 2014</ref>
== Affiliations == ACBSP holds membership and/or recognition in the following networks: * [[Universidad Argentina de la Empresa]] - UADE <ref>{{cite web|title=MBA Glossary: ACBSP |url=http://www.onlinemba.com/blog/mba-glossary-acbsp/ |website=MBA Warrior Blog |date=17 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819082911/http://www.onlinemba.com/blog/mba-glossary-acbsp/ |archivedate=2014-08-19 |df= }}</ref> * [[Council for Higher Education Accreditation]] - CHEA <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chea.org/pdf/Recognition/2011_09_20_Recognition%20Summary%20for%20ACBSP.pdf |title=Recognition Summary ACSBP |publisher=ACBSP |date=2011-09-20 |accessdate=2016-01-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304090157/http://www.chea.org/pdf/Recognition/2011_09_20_Recognition%20Summary%20for%20ACBSP.pdf |archive-date=2016-03-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> * [[European Association for Quality Assurance in Higher Education]] (Affiliate Status) - ENQA <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.enqa.eu/affil_det.lasso?id=104&cont=affiliate |title=Affiliates - Detail View |website=ENQA |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131204215840/http://www.enqa.eu/affil_det.lasso?id=104&cont=affiliate |archivedate=December 4, 2013 |accessdate=July 29, 2013}}</ref> * [[International Network for Quality Assurance Agencies in Higher Education]] - INQAAHE <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inqaahe.org/members/list-full.php |title=Members |publisher=Inqaahe |date= |accessdate=2016-01-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160113081235/http://www.inqaahe.org/members/list-full.php |archivedate=2016-01-13 }}</ref> * Association of African Business Schools - AABS <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aabschools.com/page/directory/accreditors.html |title=AABS - Academic Accreditation Bodies |publisher=Aabschools.com |date= |accessdate=2016-01-17}}</ref> * Principles for Responsible Management Education - PRME <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unprme.org/participants/view-supporting-org.php?partid=2920 |title=PRME - Participants - Supporting Organisations |publisher=Unprme.org |date=2012-12-20 |accessdate=2016-01-17}}</ref> * Consejo Latinoamericano de Escuelas de Administración - CLADEA <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cladea.org/home/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=526:acbsp-association- |title=Consejo Latinoamericano de Escuelas de Administración |publisher=Cladea.org |date= |accessdate=2016-01-17}}</ref> * Russian Association of Business Education - RABE <ref>{{cite web |title=ACBSP Bringing Together Those Dedicated to Teaching Excellence|url=http://rabe.guu.ru/downloads/file/От%20ACBSP.pdf|website=Российская Ассоциация Бизнес-Образования|publisher=Accreditation Council for Business Schools & Programs |date = 13 September 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140605060705/http://rabe.guu.ru/downloads/file/%D0%9E%D1%82%20ACBSP.pdf |archive-date=2014-06-05}}</ref> * Association of Indian Management Schools - AIMS <ref>{{cite web|title=Guest Post: Assuring Quality Business Education in India |url=http://www.onlinemba.com/blog/guest-post-assuring-quality-business-education-in-india/ |website=MBA Warrior Blog |date=10 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140605053114/http://www.onlinemba.com/blog/guest-post-assuring-quality-business-education-in-india/ |archivedate=2014-06-05 |df= }}</ref> * [[Global Management Challenge]], USA <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.usamanagementchallenge.com/partners |title=Partners |website=Global Management Challenge USA |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120118034137/http://www.usamanagementchallenge.com/partners |archivedate=January 18, 2012 |accessdate=June 18, 2013}}</ref> * [[Enactus]] <ref>{{cite web |title=Enactus|url=http://www.acbsp.org/members/?id=23455205|website=Accreditation Council for Business Schools & Programs}}</ref> * [[Federation of Swiss Private Schools]]/Swiss Private School Register <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.swissprivateschoolregister.com/fileadmin/redaktion/pdf/en/Internationally_Recognized_Accreditations.pdf |title=Internationally Recognized Accreditations |accessdate=2016-01-17}}</ref> * ACBSP has recognized certification program standards which allow for certifications to be awarded to top ACBSP students who meet the exam and GPA requirements. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gafm.org/ACBSP.pdf|title=ACBSP Certification Agreement|last=ACBSP Certification Agreement|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Honor societies == Through an agreement made in January 1992 between [[Delta Mu Delta]] and ACBSP, establishment of [[Delta Mu Delta]] chapters is now exclusively at colleges and universities with business programs which are accredited by ACBSP at the baccalaureate/graduate levels.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acbsp.org/p/cm/ld/fid=21 |title=Awards and Honor Societies |website=Accreditation Council for Business Schools & Programs |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130512015141/http://www.acbsp.org/p/cm/ld/fid%3D21 |archivedate=May 12, 2013 |accessdate=June 18, 2013 }}</ref> Delta Mu Delta was founded in 1913 by the Dean from [[Harvard University]] and four professors from [[Yale University]] and [[New York University]] to recognize students in accredited business schools for their high academic achievement in baccalaureate, masters and doctorate programs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deltamudelta.org/about/history/ |title=History - Delta Mu Delta International Honors Society | Delta Mu Delta International Honors Society |publisher=Deltamudelta.org |date= |accessdate=2016-01-17}}</ref> The ACBSP also recognizes the Kappa Beta Delta business honor society <ref>{{cite web |title=Honor Societies |url=http://www.midlandstech.com/business/acbsp_region3/honor_soc.htm|website=Midlands Technical College |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030901035113/http://www.midlandstech.com/business/acbsp_region3/honor_soc.htm |archive-date=2003-09-01}}</ref> and the [[Sigma Beta Delta]] business honor society.<ref>{{cite web |title=Delta Mu Delta|url=http://www.acbsp.org/?page=dmd|website=Accreditation Council for Business Schools & Programs}}</ref> Membership in the honor societies is also available to online students who are attending ACBSP accredited programs.
== Employer recognition == In 2006, [[Intel]] announced that it would no longer provide tuition reimbursement for employees to attend business schools with accreditation from ACBSP, accepting only [[AACSB]] accredited courses. At the same time the company imposed a similar restriction on reimbursements for engineering programs. The company explained that the policy change was intended to make the program more cost-effective to the company, noting that employees had been receiving reimbursement for programs "that were not of the highest value to the company" or left Intel after finishing programs that did not advance their careers there.<ref>Gilbertson, Dawn (December 5, 2006). "Intel cuts tuition aid for University of Phoenix classes". ''[[The Arizona Republic]]''.</ref><ref>Stu Woo, Intel Cuts 100 Colleges From Its Tuition-Reimbursement Program for Employees, ''[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]]'', February 2, 2007.</ref><ref>Dillon, Sam (February 11, 2007). "[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/11/education/11phoenix.html Troubles Grow for a University Built on Profits]". ''[[The New York Times]]'', February 11, 2007.</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/portland/stories/2007/05/28/focus5.html?page=all |date=May 27, 2007 |title=Employers cut MBA students' tuition benefits |newspaper=Portland Business Journal |location=Portland, Oregon}}</ref>

{{Infobox organization | name = American Teachers Association | native_name = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = | motto = | predecessor = National Colored Teachers Association (1906-1907)
National Association of Teachers in Colored Schools (1907-1937) | merged = [[National Education Association]] | successor = | formation = 1937 | founder = | extinction = | merger = 1966 | type = Professional association
Union | tax_id = | registration_id = | status = | purpose = | headquarters = | location = | coords = | region = | services = | products = | methods = | fields = | membership = | language = English | owner = | sec_gen = | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = | revenue = | disbursements = | expenses = | endowment = | staff = | volunteers = | slogan = | mission = | website = | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }} {{Education in the U.S.}} The '''American Teachers Association''' was a professional association and teachers' union representing teachers in schools in the South for [[people of color]] during the period of legal [[racial segregation]] in United States. In 1954 the [[United States Supreme Court]] ruled in ''[[Brown v. Board of Education]]'' that segregation of public schools was unconstitutional. The [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]] ended legal segregation. == History == In 1906, at a meeting of the Negro Young Peoples Christian and Educational Congress, the '''National Colored Teachers Association''' was formed. In 1907, to reflect that many white teachers also worked in colored schools, the name was changed to the '''National Association of Teachers in Colored Schools''' (NATCS).Perry, Thelma D., ''History of the American Teachers Association'' (Washington, D.C.: National Education Association, 1975) The members were dealing with segregated schools in the South, which had been established in law. Additional racial segregation and [[Jim Crow]] laws had been imposed by white-dominated legislatures in the late 19th century. In addition, blacks had been [[Disfranchisement after Reconstruction era|disfranchised]] since the turn of the 20th century by provisions of new constitutions and laws in the South. With blacks closed out of the political process, educators found that black public schools in the segregated states were historically underfunded, and their teachers were paid less than white teachers in white schools. 1923 was a pivotal year for the organization. [[Mary McLeod Bethune]] became its first female president{{cite book|last1=Sicherman|first1=Barbara|last2=Green|first2=Carol H.|title=Notable American Women: The Modern Period : a Biographical Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CfGHM9KU7aEC&pg=PA78|accessdate=27 April 2013|year=1980|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=9780674627338|pages=78–}} and it published its first edition of ''The Bulletin'', the official magazine.{{cite book|last=Jones-Wilson|first=Faustine C.|title=Encyclopedia of African-American education|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ni2qhq1n1d4C&pg=PA318|accessdate=27 April 2013|year=1996|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=9780313289316|pages=318–}} The magazine "was a bridge between the members of the Association, and it served to inform the public and interpret NATCS to those who did not attend the annual meetings". The 1927 president was [[William J. Hale]], the first president of [[Tennessee State University]], a historically black university in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].{{cite news|title=Black History Month: William J. Hale a leader in education|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/news/local/2014/02/06/black-history-month-william-j-hale-a-leader-in-education/5249211/|accessdate=December 18, 2017|work=The Tennessean|date=February 6, 2014}} In 1937, members changed the name to the American Teachers Association (ATA).{{cite book|last=Tillman|first=Linda C.|title=The SAGE Handbook of African American Education|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fv4aSHxEBHgC&pg=PA71|accessdate=27 April 2013|year=2009|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=9781412937436|pages=71–}} The ATA worked jointly with the [[National Education Association]] (NEA) on issues related to African-American education.{{cite web|title=Guide to the National Education Association-Special Collections records|url=http://library.gwu.edu/ead/nea1007.xml#ref2460|accessdate=April 1, 2013}} In 1926, an informal NEA committee was appointed to study issues in colored schools. That began a period of cooperation between the two associations. Following the [[United States Supreme Court]] ruling in ''[[Brown v. Board of Education]]'' (1954) that segregated schools were unconstitutional, public schools were gradually integrated after massive resistance. The [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]] prohibited legal segregation of public facilities. The ATA and NEA began to consider a merger in the early 1960s, as a result of changes in education and the [[civil rights movement]]. In 1963, the ATA voted a "qualified recommendation" in favor of merger, which was completed in 1966.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/03/us/walter-ridley-86-who-broke-color-barrier-to-get-phd-dies.html|title=Walter Ridley, 86, Who Broke Color Barrier to Get Ph.D., Dies|last=Jr.|first=Robert Mcg. Thomas|date=3 November 1996|work=The New York Times|page=51|accessdate=27 April 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1963/08/04/archives/negro-teachers-favor-nealink-but-national-group-qualifies-its.html|title=NEGRO TEACHERS FAVOR N.E.A.LINK; But National Group Qualifies Its Support for Merger 'Glaring Lack' of Negroes Formed as Protest|last=Terte|first=Robert H.|date=August 4, 1963|work=[[The New York Times]]|page=71|accessdate=27 April 2013}} The name of the merged association remained the [[National Education Association]]. == Purpose == The ATA did not support collective bargaining for its members. Instead, they sought to improve the status of education for African Americans in the South by: # Improving teaching methods. # Urging legislation for the improvement of schools. # Collecting and publishing data covering the material contributions that Negroes were making toward their own education. # Building more and better school houses, through fund-raising efforts. (Among these in the 1930s were [[Rosenwald Schools|schools]] built with the help of the [[Rosenwald Fund]] and monies raised by local black communities) # Supplementing teacher's income and pushing for an extended school year. # Co-operating with local public school boards. # Broadening the Association's scope to include private and religious schools.{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} == Notable Members == * [[C. Louise Boehringer]], Secretary of the Arizona State Teacher's Association, 1919{{cite book|last1=Binheim|first1=Max|last2=Elvin |first2=Charles A. |title=Women of the West: A Series of Biographical Sketches of Living Eminent Women in the Eleven Western States of the United States of America|year=1928|location=Los Angeles |publisher=Publishers Press|url=https://archive.org/details/womenofwestserie00binh|accessdate=August 6, 2017}}{{PD-notice}} == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == * [http://www.nea.org/home/11174.htm Short history located on the NEA's website] [[Category:Teacher associations based in the United States]] [[Category:Education trade unions]] [[Category:African-American history between emancipation and the Civil Rights Movement]] [[Category:Segregated schools in the United States]] [[Category:Trade unions established in 1906]]

revision.comment: Removed human harrasment
revision.text:
'''Andrej Preston''' (born c. 1986), also known under the [[pseudonym]] '''{{lang|sl|Slonček}} (meaning "little elephant" in [[Slovene language|Slovene]]), is the founder of the former [[BitTorrent (protocol)|BitTorrent]] site [[Suprnova.org]].<ref>Michael Ingram, [http://www.slyck.com/news.php?story=475 Interview with Sloncek of SuprNova], ''Slyck News'', May 11, 2004. Accessed 2008-11-07.</ref><ref name=vest>Jani Sever, [http://www.vest.si/2007/08/25/slovenski-pirat/ Slovenian Pirate] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070828090854/http://www.vest.si/2007/08/25/slovenski-pirat/ |date=August 28, 2007 }}, ''Vest'', 25 August 2007. Accessed 2008-11-07.</ref>
The Slovenian publication [[Mladina]] revealed in November 2004 that he was 18 years old and a student at the [[Waldorf education|Waldorf High School]] in [[Ljubljana]], [[Slovenia]].<ref>[http://www.carniola.org/2004/11/hunting-slovenias-little-elephant.htm Hunting Slovenia's Little Elephant] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070903084618/http://www.carniola.org/2004/11/hunting-slovenias-little-elephant.htm |date=September 3, 2007 }}, ''Mladina''. Accessed 2008-11-07.</ref> After having shut down Suprnova.org in December 2004, he became the target of a police investigation in early 2005, and two computers of his were confiscated.<ref name=vest/><ref>Thomas Mennecke, [http://www.slyck.com/news.php?story=626 Suprnova.org Closes], ''Slyck News'', December 19, 2004. Accessed 2008-11-07.</ref><ref name=ingram>Michael Ingram, [http://www.slyck.com/story1177_SuprNovaorg_The_Story_of_a_Legend SuprNova.org: The Story of a Legend], ''Slyck News'', May 7, 2006. Accessed 2008-11-07.</ref> In October 2005 the prosecutor announced that no charges would be filed and the computers were returned.<ref name=ingram/>
Andrej Preston had given the domain suprnova.org to The Pirate Bay. The Pirate Bay had relaunched it as of August 21, 2007.<ref name=vest/>
On August 25, 2007, he moved to [[San Francisco, California]],<ref name=vest/> where he is visiting [[Academy of Art University]].
Three years after donating the suprnova.org domain to The Pirate Bay, Preston retrieved it, in order to make a new website, which should become an online video portal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://activepolitic.com:82/blog/2011-01-07/SuprNova_Relaunches.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120719064535/http://activepolitic.com:82/blog/2011-01-07/SuprNova_Relaunches.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-19 |title=SuprNova Relaunches |publisher=activepolitic.com }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.sloncek.com Sloncek's Blog] Andrej Preston's blog describing his experience after he moved to USA *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070828090854/http://www.vest.si/2007/08/25/slovenski-pirat/ Vest.si], Interview with Sloncek - 25.8.2007 {{sl icon}} *[http://www.suprnova.org Suprnova.org]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Preston, Andrej}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Waldorf school alumni]] [[Category:1986 births]] [[Category:Slovenian Internet celebrities]] [[Category:BitTorrent]] [[Category:People from Ljubljana]] [[Category:Academy of Art University alumni]]
{{Slovenia-bio-stub}}

revision.text:
Assessment is a systemic process in [[higher education]] that uses [[empirical data]] on student learning to refine programs and improve student learning.<ref name=Allen2004>{{cite book|last1=Allen|first1=M.J.|title=Assessing Academic Programs in Higher Education|date=2004|publisher=Jossey-Bass|location=San Francisco}}</ref> As a continuous process, assessment establishes measurable and clear student learning outcomes for learning, provisioning a sufficient amount of learning opportunities to achieve these outcomes, implementing a systematic way of gathering, analyzing and interpreting evidence to determine how well student learning matches expectations, and using the collected information to inform improvement in student learning.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Suskie|first1=Linda|title=Assessing Student Learning|date=2004|publisher=Anker|location=Bolton, MA}}</ref> Assessment functions as part of a continuous process whereby the parts of the cycle are revised and monitored. The term “assessment” is defined broadly in that any outcome or goal in any activity or discipline can be a part of this process.
==Types== Assessment in higher education can focus on the individual learner, a course, an academic program, or the institution.
# Course-level Assessment # Program-level Assessment
===Course-level Assessment=== Assessment embedded at the course level (sometimes referred to as embedded assessment or authentic assessment) typically involves the use of assignments.<ref name="NC State University2017">{{cite web|last1=NC State University|title=Course-based Assessment Overview|url=https://assessment.dasa.ncsu.edu/wp-content/uploads/sites/53/2015/12/methods_course.pdf|website=NC State Division of Academic and Student Affairs|accessdate=2 March 2017}}</ref> Students receive feedback on their performance on assignments and faculty gain knowledge of student learning to use for grading.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Whelburg|first1=C.M.|title=Promoting Integrative and Transformative Assessment|date=2008|publisher=Jossey-Bass|location=San Francisco}}</ref> The work assessed within courses best relates to specific program-level student learning outcomes. Angelo and Cross<ref name=Angelo1993>{{cite book|last1=Angelo|first1=Thomas|last2=Cross|first2=K. Patricia|title=Classroom Assessment Techniques: A Handbook for College Teachers|date=1993|publisher=Josses-Bass|location=San Francisco: CA|isbn=1555425003}}</ref> believe assessment in the classroom is an important part of the faculty feedback loop which can provide meaningful information about their effectiveness as teachers while also giving students a measure of their progress as learners.
===Program-level Assessment=== Program assessment is a best practice in higher education.<ref name=Allen2004 /> The process involves a framework for placing priority and attention on the process of student learning and most specifically, the program objectives, organization of curriculum, pedagogy and student development.<ref name=Allen2004 /> Like course assessment, program assessment requires defining a statement of mission/goals, establishment of program-specific student learning outcomes and the identification of where learning takes place or “learning opportunities”. The next part in program assessment involves the development of a research question or intended goal for assessment. What questions does the program seek to answer? And what direct or indirect evidence needs to be collected to identify answers? The collected data is evaluated, analyzed and interpreted resulting in the implementation of an action plan resulting in improvement in the program and student learning.<ref>{{cite web|last1=University of Hawaii at Manoa Assessment Office|title=Basic Steps of Program Assessment|url=http://manoa.hawaii.edu/assessment/howto/plan.htm|accessdate=2 March 2017}}</ref>
==== Mission Alignment ==== Each course a student takes occurs within the context of a program, which occurs within the context of overarching university outcomes. With the assumption that coursework should support the program and programs should support the overall mission of the university, alignment of mission (and learning outcomes) should occur. Assessment at the course level typically takes the form of tests, quizzes, and assignments. When courses are mapped to program outcomes, this permits the aggregation of data from several courses covering the same outcome which can be used for program assessment. Additional program assessment can take the form of embedded assignments, field experiences, capstone experiences, portfolios, or tests of majors.
==== Scoring Guides/Rubrics ==== [[Rubrics]] are often used to assess student work. Essentially, a rubric is a scoring guide grid consisting of a scale of some sort (i.e., levels of performance), the dimensions or important components of an assignment, and descriptions of what constitutes each level of performance for each assignment dimension. Rubrics can be particularly effective for assessment due to how closely they are tied with the teaching and learning process - they can be used for grading, as well as giving students feedback on their performance.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Stevens|first1=D.D.|author2=A.J. Levi|title=Introduction to Rubrics|date=2013|publisher=Stylus|location=Sterling}}</ref>
==== Assessment Points ==== Assessment is most effective when it occurs at multiple points in time along the student's path. Multiple measures over time provide a way to triangulate data and increase confidence in the results.
==== Effective Assignments ==== In order to assess student learning, students must given assignment where they can demonstrate what they know and can do.
==== Indirect/Direct Measures ==== A distinction is made between direct and indirect measures of learning. Direct measures, as their name implies, involve directly examining student work products to assess the achievement of learning outcomes. These work products occur in a variety of formats including objective tests, and rubric-scored projects, performances, and written work. A recent survey of provosts indicates that classroom based assessment and rubrics are most frequently used. Large scale commercial tests such as the College Learning Assessment (CLA) are used by fewer than 50% use standardized tests according to the survey. Indirect measures focus on data from which one can make inferences about learning. Indirect measures can include surveys on student and faculty perceptions about learning, focus groups, and exit interviews. National surveys such as the National Survey of Student Engagement (NSSE) have become increasing popular indirect measures, with roughly 85% of institutions using these measures according to a recent survey.
==== Sampling ==== In a classroom setting or in a program level assessment, it is often possible to assess the entire population of interest, referred to as a census. However, it is sometimes impractical or ineffective to assess an entire population, due to the time and effort involved as well as survey fatigue if the same group of students are being asked to take multiple surveys. Therefore, sampling strategies can be used to pick a subset of the population of interest. The goal of sampling is to select a smaller group that represents the population on key characteristics. Multiple sampling approaches are commonly used in higher education assessment, including [[random sampling|random]] and [[stratified sampling]]. In a random sample, each individual is equally likely to be selected. In a stratified sample, individuals are grouped based on specific characteristics of interest and then randomly selected from each group to ensure adequate numbers of each group.
==== Use of findings ==== Assessment data are only effective in "closing the loop" and improving programs if they are shared and communicated widely.
==== Benchmarking ==== Benchmarking is a way for an institution or program to determine how a sample measures up to others or to themselves at an earlier time.
=== Professional Organizations === There are numerous regional organizations dedicated to discussing issues and policies related to assessment in higher education. The Association for the Assessment of Learning in Higher Education (AALHE) is one international organization. Seven other regional assessment organizations exist in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|title=Virginia Assessment Group|url=http://virginiaassessment.org|website=Virginia Assessment Group Website|accessdate=10 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Chicago Area Assessment Group|url=http://www.chicagoassessment.org|website=CAAG: Chicago Area Assessment Group|accessdate=10 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Washington Area Student Learning Assessment Network|url=https://academicplanning.gwu.edu/waslan|website=The George Washington University Office of Academic Planning & Assessment|accessdate=10 March 2017}}</ref>
In an interview with the Chronicle for Higher Education, Marsha Watson, former director of the AALHE, stated that the “rising demands for accountability mean that assessment must evolve into its own discipline."<ref name="chronicle">{{cite web|last1=Glenn|first1=David|title=Learning-Assessment Specialists to Gather at Group's First Conference|url=http://www.chronicle.com/article/Learning-Assessment/127751|website=The Chronicle of Higher Education|accessdate=28 March 2017}}</ref>
The National Institute for Learning Outcomes Assessment is another organization dedicated to helping institutions use assessment data to improve academic quality. They have delivered a number of research papers on assessment practices.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Suskie|first1=Linda|title=Why Are We Assessing|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/views/2010/10/26/why-are-we-assessing|website=Inside Higher Ed|accessdate=28 March 2017}}</ref>
===Benefits of Assessment=== There is heightened political and public pressure on higher education institutions to explain what they are trying to do and provide evidence they are actually doing it.<ref name=Angelo1993/> Faculty want students to learn. In addition, faculty love their disciplines and want to share their knowledge and enthusiasm with students. Placing emphasis on what students learn and what students do helps to effectively drive improvement in the learning process, program planning and overall institutional improvement.<ref name=Angelo1993/> Assessment adds transparency to the teaching and learning process, helps to provide some evidence to the effectiveness of student learning and promotes an environment where continuous improvement is well understood and ingrained in the institutional culture.
Linda Suskie, a higher education consultant, says that "Good assessments are not once-and-done affairs. They are part of an ongoing, organized, and systematized effort to understand and improve teaching and learning.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Suskie|first1=Linda|title=Assessing student learning: A common sense guide|publisher=John Wiley & Songs, Inc.|pages=50}}</ref>”
===Criticism of Assessment=== Some university faculty and researchers have criticized student learning outcomes assessment in higher education. Robert Shireman, a senior fellow for the Century Foundation, argued that accrediting agencies often require institutions to reduce learning to meaningless blurbs, or student learning outcomes, which “prevents rather than leads to the type of quality assurance that has student work at the center.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Shireman|first1=Robert Shireman|title=SLO Madness|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/views/2016/04/07/essay-how-fixation-inane-student-learning-outcomes-fails-ensure-academic-quality|website=Inside Higher Ed|accessdate=10 April 2017}}</ref>” Erik Gilbert, a professor of History, wrote another notable essay criticizing assessment in higher education arguing that it has little effect on educational quality and that accrediting agencies require institutions to invest time and resources in collecting evidence on student learning even though, he believes, that it does not improve academic quality.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gilbert|first1=Erik|title=Does Assessment Make Colleges Better? Who Knows?|url=http://www.chronicle.com/article/Does-Assessment-Make-Colleges/232371/|website=The Chronicle of Higher Education|accessdate=10 April 2017}}</ref> Molly Worthen <ref>{{cite web|last1=Worthen|first1=Molly|title=The Misguided Drive to Measure ‘Learning Outcomes’|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/23/opinion/sunday/colleges-measure-learning-outcomes.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=16 April 2018}}</ref>also criticized assessment for its seeming lack of empirical evidence indicating it improves student learning. However, Matthew Fuller <ref>{{cite web|last1=Fuller|first1=Matthew|title=Assessment Culture Research|url=http://www.shsu.edu/research/survey-of-assessment-culture/research.html|website=Survey of Assessment Culture|accessdate=16 April 2018}}</ref>and others have developed the Surveys of Assessment Culture, aimed at examining the foundations of institutional cultures of assessment through empirical studies.
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Program Evaluation}} [[Category:Impact assessment]] [[Category:Educational evaluation methods]] [[Category:Educational accreditation| ]] [[Category:Accreditation]]

revision.text:
'''Bachelor of Social Services''' (called ''socionom'' in Swedish and Danish, ''sosionom'' in Norwegian, and ''sosionomi'' in Finnish) is a degree in [[social welfare]] from [[Scandinavia]]n universities. At the core it is based on the competences needed to work in social services. Courses in [[sociology]], [[human rights]], [[gerontology]], [[Community practice|community services]], [[psychology]], [[social security]] and [[entrepreneurship]] are part of the degree. Service orientation and client work is seen through a [[Social pedagogy|social pedagogical]] framework. The studies take 3 to 5 years. Degree holders are usually hired for services in [[Nordic model|Scandinavian welfare systems]]. [[NGO]] oriented services take place with families and people of all ages in areas such as: child protection, early childhood education, community work, substance abuse prevention or promotion of mental health. Students with a BSW can pursue an advanced standing track for master's in social work programs.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.onlinemswprograms.com/advanced-standing-online-msw-programs.html|title=Online Advanced Standing MSW Programs: Complete List of Schools|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}</ref>
In Sweden, the training was originally given in [[social work]] than in social services, training's were given in specialized social work colleges (''socialhögskola''), which were integrated into the regular Swedish university system in 1977, through department of social work at an existing university or university college.
==Job titles== Bachelors of Social Services graduates find jobs in a wide range of roles in the social services. Some may be in the public, private or the third sector. <ref>https://www.laurea.fi/en/studying-and-applying/bachelors-programmes-in-english/social-services</ref>
*Social welfare supervisor *Family worker *Student welfare officer *Project worker *Project manager *NGO employee *Service entrepreneur *Social welfare officer
==Notable degree holders== *[[Athar Ali (politician)|Athar Ali]] *[[Krishna Chudasama]] *[[Anne Enger]] *[[Bo Holmberg]] *[[Kuupik Kleist]] *[[Lars Leijonborg]] *[[Gudrun Schyman]] *[[Anna Sjödin]] *[[Ola Ullsten]] *[[Olle Gunnar Westling]]
{{Social work}}

revision.text:
The '''Biscuit Fire publication controversy''' was an academic and political controversy in the [[United States]] in January 2006 about publication of an academic paper titled ''Post-wildfire logging hinders regeneration and increases fire risk''. The [[United States Forest Service|U.S Forest Service]] and a group of professors, including six at the [[Oregon State University]] College of [[Forestry]], wrote a letter to the prestigious scientific journal ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' requesting that publication of a short forestry paper written by an OSU Forestry graduate student and others be delayed until the authors could respond to it, arguing the article was "short on qualifiers and context".<ref>{{cite news |last=Milstein |first=Michael |url=http://www.oregonlive.com/news/oregonian/index.ssf?/base/news/1137729313106480.xml&coll=7 |work=[[The Oregonian]] |title=Logging study sets off own firestorm |date=2006-01-20 |accessdate=2007-12-27 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061211071006/http://www.oregonlive.com/news/oregonian/index.ssf?%2Fbase%2Fnews%2F1137729313106480.xml&coll=7 |archivedate=2006-12-11 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The group requested alternatively that ''Science'' publish a sidebar illustrating their concerns alongside the paper. ''Science'' refused, and the paper, which had already undergone [[peer review]] and been approved for publication, appeared in the January 20, 2006 issue. The paper had been published in the online edition of ''Science'' before the letter was written.
== ''Science'' article == The paper, written by graduate student Dan Donato and several colleagues, concerned the effects of logging in the aftermath of the 2002 [[Biscuit Fire]], a massive [[wildfire]] which burned nearly a half million acres (2,000 km²) in southwestern Oregon. Some forestry scientists, and the [[George W. Bush administration|Bush administration]], proposed that [[salvage logging]]—removal of dead trees, many still usable as [[timber]], after a fire—was necessary for fire safety and forest regeneration.<ref>Sessions, J., P. Bettinger, R. Buckman, M. Newton, and J. Hamann. 2004. Hastening the return of complex forests following fire: The consequences of delay. Journal of Forestry 102(3):38-45.</ref> Donato ''et al.'''s research provided some evidence contradicting this view. They compared sections of the burn which were burned severely and then salvage-logged to sections which had only been burned. They found the unlogged portions had significantly more [[conifer]] seedlings than were found in the logged portions. The paper suggested that soil disturbance and materials left over from the logging process may have disturbed the growth of seedlings. The paper also reported elevated surface fuels in the logged sites, which they concluded elevated the risk of future fire.
== Political involvement == The incident and its aftermath had significant repercussions in the forestry community, and highlighted the political obstacles surrounding much of forestry science and research. When the letter first came to light the College of Forestry was subjected to heavy criticism from both within and outside for what many perceived as an unwarranted attack on [[academic freedom]].<ref>[http://www.the-scientist.com/news/display/23016/ Wildfire logging debate heats up]</ref> Accusations of politically motivated bias were made by both sides, and critics of the incident noted that the College received 10% of its funding from a tax on [[logging]], and that many professors had ties with the Forest Service and the logging industry. Defenders of the college noted that the vast majority of research in the college was funded by competitive grants, and that collaboration with government agencies and relevant industries is common across the sciences.<ref>[http://mrzine.monthlyreview.org/york240106.html MR Zine: Corporate Forestry and Academic Freedom]</ref> Hal Salwasser, the dean of the College of Forestry, eventually survived a vote of confidence, apologized for his part in the controversy (but not for calling environmentalists "goons" <ref>http://www.gazettetimes.com/news/opinion/letters-osu-forestry-dean-hal-salwasser-should-be-fired/article_90d55382-8c09-5be0-982c-a641b8b5be6e.html</ref><ref>http://articles.latimes.com/2006/jun/11/nation/na-salvage11</ref>), and reaffirmed OSU's support for academic freedom.
The letter's primary author, OSU forestry engineering professor John Sessions, claimed that the paper's publication constituted a failure of the peer review process, and that he would appeal the matter to the board of ''Science''.<ref>[http://heraldnet.com/article/20060202/NEWS02/602020756 The Herald: Forestry professor continues to fight anti-logging research]</ref> ''Science'' editor-in-chief [[Donald Kennedy]] said in a letter to ''[[The Oregonian]]'' that it "would be foolish to argue that no consideration of the political extensions of this finding could have entered the decision" regarding publication; however, he believes that the paper would have "made it (to publication) on its own".
== Ongoing research and discussion== The August 4, 2006 issue of ''Science'' contained comments by the OSU professors,<ref>[http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/full/313/5787/615a M. Newton, S. Fitzgerald, R. R. Rose, P. W. Adams, S. D. Tesch, J. Sessions,* T. Atzet, R. F. Powers, C. Skinner, "Comment on 'Post-Wildfire Logging Hinders Regeneration and Increases Fire Risk'", ''Science'', Aug 4 2006]</ref> congressman [[Brian Baird]],<ref>[http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/full/313/5787/615b B. N. Baird, "Comment on 'Post-Wildfire Logging Hinders Regeneration and Increases Fire Risk'", ''Science'', Aug 4 2006]</ref> and a response from Donato and his colleagues.<ref>[http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/full/313/5787/615c D. C. Donato, J. B. Fontaine, J. L. Campbell, W. D. Robinson, J. B. Kauffman, B. E. Law "Response to Comments on 'Post-Wildfire Logging Hinders Regeneration and Increases Fire Risk'", ''Science'', Aug 4 2006]</ref> [[Evergreen Magazine]] subsequently dedicated an entire issue to a discussion of the controversy.<ref>[http://evergreenmagazine.com/ Skinner, D. 2006 "The Donato-Law Fiasco: Mixing Politics & Science: Alchemy at OSU", ''Evergreen'', Winter, 2006-2007]</ref>
In the following year two new papers partially substantiated Donato's findings. Natural conifer regeneration following severe fires in the Siskiyou Klamath region was common, and stocking standards were always exceeded without planting, although natural regenerated conifers grew slower than planted conifers.<ref>Shatford, J. P. A., D. E. Hibbs, and K. J. Puettmann. 2007. Conifer regeneration after forest fire in the Klamath-Siskiyous: How much, how soon? Journal of Forestry 105:139-146.</ref> Thompson and others found that the Biscuit Fire severity was higher in areas that had been burned and salvaged fifteen years earlier (1987) than it was in comparable areas that were burned in 1987 but left unmanaged.<ref>Thompson, J. R., T. A. Spies, and L. M. Ganio. 2007. Reburn severity in managed and unmanaged vegetation in a large wildfire. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the USA 104:10743-10748.</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/311/5759/352 D.C. Donato ''et al.'', "Post-wildfire logging hinders regeneration and increases fire risk," ''Science'', January 20, 2006 (subscription required)]
{{OSUtemplate}}

revision.comment: /* top */[[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests_for_approval/PrimeBOT_28|Task 28]] - removal of deprecated parameters from [[Template:infobox company]] (+ genfixes)
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{orphan|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox company |name = Carnage UK |logo = |type = [[Private company limited by shares|Private]] |foundation = June 2007 |location_city = Birmingham |location_country = UK |key_people = Paul Bahia |industry = University student entertainment |products = [[Pub crawl]]s |num_employees = |parent = Varsity Leisure Group (VLG) Ltd |homepage = [http://www.carnageuk.com Carnage UK] }}
'''Carnage UK''' is a company that organises drinking events for students in the United Kingdom. The idea for Carnage UK was originally taken from a University of Birmingham event 'Carnage' run by the University's raising-and-giving society Carnival Rag. The original Carnage has since been rebranded to 'Karma', with all proceeds going to charity.<ref name="Greatrex2012">{{cite web|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/local-news/carnage-set-for-a-rebranded-return-for-birmingham-231399|last=Greatrex|first=Jonny|date=10 September 2012|accessdate=17 November 2014|title=Carnage set for a rebranded return for Birmingham university freshers|newspaper=[[Birmingham Mail]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141117114515/http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/local-news/carnage-set-for-a-rebranded-return-for-birmingham-231399|archivedate=17 November 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref>
==Market share== They arrange events for an estimated 350,000 undergraduate students in 45 towns and cities each year. The company charges students £10 for which they receive a t-shirt and free entry to around 10 pubs, bars and nightclubs. Many of the venues offer drinks promotions during the events. It is "owned" by [[Varsity Leisure Group]].<ref name="Observer">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2009/nov/08/philip-laing-carnage-binge-drinking|title=Student pub crawls face ban amid backlash over drunken disorder|last=Hill|first=Amelia |date=8 November 2009 |work=The Observer|accessdate=8 November 2009 | location=London}}</ref>
==Incidents==
===University of Bath=== In 2008 a student at the [[University of Bath]] hanged himself behind a nightclub during an event organised by Carnage UK.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/3497326/Straight-A-student-found-hanged-after-Carnage-UK-pub-crawl.html|title=Straight A student found hanged after Carnage UK pub crawl|last=Savill |first=Richard |date=21 November 2008|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=8 November 2009 | location=London}}</ref>
===Sheffield Hallam University=== In October 2009, A Sports Technology student at [[Sheffield Hallam University]], was photographed urinating<ref>http://www.thestar.co.uk/news/The-moment-a-student-urinated.5740115.jp?CommentPage=6&CommentPageLength=10 Sheffield Star</ref> on a [[war memorial]] in [[Barker's Pool]] after drinking for several hours on a bar crawl organised by Carnage UK. The photograph was later published in a number of newspapers. The student pleaded guilty to outraging public decency. The judge in the case said that he felt the student's actions were directly caused by his heavy consumption of alcohol and that Carnage UK should also have been present in court.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/6501638/Judge-highlights-Carnage-UKs-role-in-war-memorial-incident.html|title=Judge highlights Carnage UK's role in war memorial incident|last=Stokes|first=Paul|date=5 November 2009|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=8 November 2009 | location=London}}</ref> Responding to this criticism a press officer for Carnage UK told ''[[PR Week]]'' that much of the press coverage over the incident had been unfair. He pointed out that more than 2000 students attended the event and that the student who urinated was responsible for his own actions.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://prweek.com/uk/news/964700/Carnage-UK-press-team-hits-back-negative-media-coverage/ |title=Carnage UK press team hits back at negative media coverage |last=O'Reilly |first=Gemma |date=8 November 2009 |publisher=PR Week |accessdate=8 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091108023154/http://www.prweek.com/uk/news/964700/Carnage-UK-press-team-hits-back-negative-media-coverage/ |archivedate=8 November 2009 |df= }}</ref>
===University of Exeter=== After an event in [[Exeter]] in October 2009 it was reported that the police are to consider charging the company for the extra police officers that must be deployed whilst their events are run.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thisisexeter.co.uk/news/Exeter-Carnage-UK-policing-costs/article-1456551-detail/article.html|title=Exeter Carnage UK policing costs call|date=27 October 2009|publisher=This is Exeter|accessdate=8 November 2009}}</ref>
===Bangor=== In March 2009, a 61-year-old man was assaulted by one of its organisers after he asked about arrangements regarding to the event,.<ref>http://www.theonlinemail.co.uk/bangor-and-anglesey-news/local-bangor-and-anglesey-news/2010/03/24/bangor-events-boss-assaulted-neighbour-66580-26091321/</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/7480936/Carnage-pub-crawl-operator-punched-elderly-man.html | work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London | title=Carnage pub crawl operator 'punched elderly man' A national organiser for controversial student pub crawl firm Carnage UK punched unconscious a resident who voiced concerns about noise levels at one of their events, a court heard today. | date=19 March 2010 | accessdate=28 April 2010}}</ref>
===Southampton=== In October 2010, another heavily intoxicated student, this time from the [[Southampton University]], was photographed urinating on a war memorial.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1317897/Carnage-student-urinates-war-memorial-just-year-Philip-Laing-escaped-jail-insult.html | location=London | work=Daily Mail | date=6 October 2010}}</ref>
===Cardiff=== In June 2014, the Daily Mail reported that a group of drunken women emerged from a Carnage pub in Cardiff and commenced verbally abusing, and physically assaulting, a homeless man, initially profanely yelling at him to get a job, then dragging him across the pavement and street, punching him, pulling his trousers down and kicking his face.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2652681/The-Carnage-pub-crawl-girls-attacked-homeless-man-telling-f-job-Shocking-footage-streets.html | work=Daily Mail | date=9 June 2014}}</ref>
==Student organisation prohibition== The [[National Union of Students (United Kingdom)|National Union of Students]] has launched a campaign to stop the organisation hosting more events and according to a poll by ''The Observer'' at least 17 student unions have banned them from advertising on their premises.<ref name="Observer" />
==Binge drinking== The founder of Varsity Leisure Group, 29-year-old Inderpaul Sandeep Singh Bahia has denied that the company encourages [[binge drinking]] saying, ''"Our events are heavily focused on group identity, social and ethical cohesion, and fancy dress themes."''<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/6502069/Carnage-UK-controversial-bar-crawl-promoter.html|title=Carnage UK: controversial bar crawl promoter|date=4 November 2009|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=8 November 2009 | location=London}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.carnageuk.com/ Carnage UK website] * [http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/features/article2708141.ece ''The Sun'' October 2009]
[[Category:Drinking culture]] [[Category:Student culture]] [[Category:Leisure companies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Companies based in Birmingham, West Midlands]] [[Category:British companies established in 2007]]

'''Character Day''' is a global initiative — a unified day of film and discussion showcasing the science behind character development. Millions of people of all ages in schools, classrooms, companies, homes around the world engage in conversation and action around character strengths like empathy, grit, gratitude, creativity, and leadership.<ref name="The Atlantic">{{cite news|last1=Wong|first1=Alia|title=Why Civics is About More Than Citizenship|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/education/archive/2015/09/civic-education-citizenship-test/405889/|accessdate=15 June 2016|work=The Atlantic|date=September 17, 2015}}</ref> In 2018, there were over 200,000 Character Day events around the world.
==History==
Character Day was co-created in 2014 by [[Tiffany Shlain]], co-founder of the non-profit Let it Ripple, founder of the [[Webby Awards]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Schwartzberg|first1=Louie|title=Interview with Tiffany Shlain|url=http://gratituderevealed.com/tiffany-shlain/?goal=0_03bcd331af-0e4e530f87-344525421&mc_cid=0e4e530f87&mc_eid=f6ee5c7425|accessdate=15 June 2016|work=Gratitude Revealed|date=May 26, 2016}}</ref> and co-founder of the [[International Academy of Digital Arts and Sciences]] along with Sawyer Steele, co-founder of Let it Ripple.<ref name="Forward">{{cite news|last1=Friedman|first1=Gabe|title=Calling All Mensches — It's Time For Your 15 Minutes of Fame|url=http://forward.com/the-assimilator/311355/calling-all-mensches-its-time-for-your-15-minutes-of-fame/|accessdate=15 June 2016|work=Forward|date=July 4, 2015}}</ref>. The first Character Day in 2014 also marked the global premiere of the short film ''The Science of Character'', which explores the social science and neuroscience behind character development.<ref name="Psychology Today">{{cite news|last1=Niemiec|first1=Ryan|title=Top 10 Amazing (Recent) Findings on Character Strengths|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/what-matters-most/201509/top-10-amazing-recent-findings-character-strengths|accessdate=15 June 2016|work=Psychology Today|date=September 9, 2015}}</ref> Shlain and Let it Ripple produced Character Day and invited schools and organizations around the world to premiere the film and discuss its ideas about character development all on the same day via a simultaneous online video conversation. There were over 1500 events in 31 countries on March 14, 2014.<ref name="jweekly">{{cite news|last1=Himmelstein|first1=Drew|title=Tiffany Shlain’s new film looks at being a mensch|url=http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/75652/tiffany-shlains-new-film-looks-at-being-a-mensch/|accessdate=15 June 2016|work=jweekly|date=September 10, 2015}}</ref> The State Department’s Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs also selected ''The Science of Character'' to be part of their American Film Program.<ref name="Jewish Business News">{{cite news|last1=Hecht|first1=Albert|title=Tiffany Shlain Receives Support From The Bezos Family Foundation For Her "Science Of Character"|url=http://jewishbusinessnews.com/2014/03/19/tiffany-shlain-receives-support-from-the-bezos-family-foundation-for-her-science-of-character/|accessdate=2 July 2016|work=Jewish Business News|date=March 19, 2014}}</ref>
On September 8, 2015, Character Day became an annual event. For the second event, Shlain and Let it Ripple premiered Shlain’s film ''The Adaptable Mind'', which explores skills needed in the 21st Century as well as ''The Making of a Mensch,'' which uses a modern-day interpretation of the Jewish teachings of [[Musar literature]] as it pertains to character development.<ref name="Sun-Sentinel">{{cite news|last1=Lieberman|first1=Randall|title=Film Includes Ancient Jewish Teachings|url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/florida-jewish-journal/news/palm/fl-jjps-makingofamensch-0916-20150915-story.html|accessdate=15 June 2016|work=Sun-Sentinel|date=June 15, 2016}}</ref> The second Character Day had over 6700 events in 41 countries.<ref name="jweekly" /> In addition, the US State Department selected ''The Adaptable Mind'' to be part of their 2016-2017 American Film Showcase.<ref name="Politico">{{cite news|last1=Stratford|first1=Michael|title=Let's Talk About Character|url=http://www.politico.com/tipsheets/morning-education/2016/06/senate-grilling-over-title-ix-guidance-214734#ixzz4B75kVHex|accessdate=15 June 2016|work=Politico|date=June 9, 2016}}</ref>
Character Day 2016 was held on September 22, 2016. There were 93,000 events in 125 countries. Character Day 2017, on September 13, 2017, had 133,000 events in 150 countries while premiering Let it Ripple’s film, "30,000 Days". Character Day 2018 on September 26, 2018, had over 210,000 events worldwide. Character Day speakers have included [[Martin Seligman]], [[Angela Duckworth]], [[Ken Robinson]], [[Krista Tippett]] and [[Moby]].
==Events==
In 2014, over 1500 schools and organizations watched ''The Science of Character'' in 31 countries with people joining the conversation online from over 120 countries.<ref name="Jewish News Greater Phoenix">{{cite news|title=Character Day 2016|url=http://www.jewishaz.com/arts_features/character-day/article_41ad73ca-21dd-11e6-af28-d354d64bfd3a.html|accessdate=2 July 2016|work=Jewish News of Greater Phoenix|date=May 25, 2016}}</ref> Experts in character education from Harvard, Yale, University of California Berkeley, and others led a virtual global Q&A. The US State Department had screenings in Washington DC and embassies around the world including Egypt and Vietnam, among others.<ref name="Politico" /> Volunteers translated the film into 14 languages including Arabic, Bulgarian, Chinese, French, German, Hindi, Japanese, Norwegian, Persian, Romanian, Russian, Serbian, Spanish and Swahili.
In 2015, Character Day screened the film ''The Adaptable Mind'' for 6,784 schools, classrooms, workplaces and organizations.<ref name="jweekly" /> Events took place in 41 countries on all inhabited continents except Antarctica. People from 125 countries participated in the online discussion.<ref name="SD Jewish Journal">{{cite news|url=http://sdjewishjournal.com/sdjj/june-2016/character-day-2016-expected-to-impact-millions-in-global-conversation/|title=Character Day 2016 Expected to Impact Millions in Global Conversation|last1=Chitayat|first1=Caline|date=June 2, 2016|work=San Diego Jewish Journal|accessdate=15 June 2016}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|3}}
==External links == *[http://tiffanyshlain.com/ Tiffany Shlain] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20141219070207/http://www.letitripple.org/sign_up?splash=1 Let It Ripple ]
